SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface SQL

public sealed interface SQL

Encapsulates a user-provided SQL statement. The statement can be parametrized in three qualitatively different ways. For each variant a different implementation of the SQL interface is provided. The implementations are hidden from view. Instances of them are obtained via static factory methods on the SQL interface itself.

Named Parameters

The simplest implementation supports the use of named parameters within SQL query strings. For example: 


 SELECT *
   FROM PERSON
  WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
    AND LAST_NAME = :lastName
  LIMIT :from, :batchSize

Named parameters are placeholders for, and will ultimately be replaced by regular JDBC parameters (that is: question marks). Thus, named parameters can and should be used wherever you would ordinarily use regular JDBC parameters. An instance of this implementation can be obtained via the SQL.basic() method. You should also preferably use this implementation for completely static SQL.

SQL Templates

A classic example of something that you often want to, but cannot parametrize with JDBC are the column(s) in the ORDER BY clause. Klojang JDBC lets you do this using Klojang Template variables. For example: 


 SELECT *
   FROM PERSON
  WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
    AND LAST_NAME = :lastName
  ORDER BY ~%sortColumn% ~%sortOrder%
  LIMIT :from, :batchSize

(Thus: named parameters look like this: :fooBar. Klojang Templates variables look like this: ~%fooBar%.)

An instance of this implementation can be obtained via the SQL.template() method. Klojang JDBC is agnostic about, and has no opinion on what gets parametrized this way. You could also parametrize the table(s) in the FROM clause for example.

SQL Skeletons

The implementation obtained via the SQL.skeleton() methods allows for very dynamically generated SQL. As with SQL templates, the SQL is provided in the form of a Klojang template (that is: it may contain Klojang Templates variables). However, SQL skeletons explicitly allow you to set template variables to values that are themselves chunks of SQL. More importantly: these chunks of SQL may again contain named parameters. Named parameters are only extracted after the SQL template has been rendered. This makes SQL skeletons less efficient, but more dynamic than SQL templates.

SQL Injection

As mentioned, named parameters are ultimately just placeholders for standard JDBC parameters (question marks). Therefore, using them carries no risk of SQL injection. This is not the case for SQL templates — that is, SQL containing Klojang Templates variables. They can appear anywhere in a SQL template, and Klojang JDBC does not make any attempt to parse, analyse or escape them. Therefore, the values you provide for SQL template variables should preferably be hard-coded somewhere in your own program. Accepting values of unknown origin is a bad idea.

  • Method Details

    • basic

      static SQL basic(String sql)
      Returns an SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL query string
      Returns:
      an instance of an SQL implementation that behaves as described above

    • basic

      static SQL basic(String sql, BindInfo bindInfo)
      Returns an SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL query string
      bindInfo - a BindInfo object that allows you to fine-tune how values are bound into the underlying PreparedStatement
      Returns:
      an instance of an SQL implementation that behaves as described above

    • skeleton

      static SQL skeleton(String sql)
      Returns an SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The template variables may be set to strings that themselves again contain named parameters. These named parameters will be detected and extracted by Klojang JDBC.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL query string
      Returns:
      an instance of an SQL implementation that behaves as described above

    • skeleton

      static SQL skeleton(String sql, BindInfo bindInfo)
      Returns an SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The template variables may be set to strings that themselves again contain named parameters. These named parameters will be detected and extracted by Klojang JDBC.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL query string
      bindInfo - a BindInfo object that allows you to fine-tune how values are bound into the underlying PreparedStatement
      Returns:
      an instance of an SQL implementation that behaves as described above

    • prepareInsert

      static SQLInsertBuilder prepareInsert()

      static SQLBatchInsertBuilder prepareBatchInsert()
      Returns an SQLBatchInsertBuilder that enables you to easily configure large batch inserts.
      Returns:
      an SQLBatchInsertBuilder that enables you to easily configure large batch inserts.

    • expression

      static Object expression(String expression)
      Returns a special object that signals to Klojang JDBC that the specified string is to be treated as an SQL expression and hence must not be quoted or escaped. You can use this when specifying transformers for beans to be saved in a batch insert. Note that this makes you responsible for ensuring that the specified string does not and cannot suffer from SQL injection. Use a Quoter to ensure that all strings in the expression are properly quoted and escaped.
      Parameters:
      expression - the string to be wrapped into the signal object
      Returns:
      a special object that signals to Klojang JDBC that the specified string is to be treated as an SQL expression
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteLiteral(String)
      • Quoter

    • session

      SQLSession session(Connection con)
      Returns a SQLSession that allows you to execute the SQL query.
      Returns:
      a SQLSession that allows you to execute the SQL query
